Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured or 'bilingual' pottery type A cup with turn of stem; interior glazed apart from tondo which has a simple band at its periphery; in tondo, black-figure decoration consisting of part of Boeotian shield and helmet crest of warrior to right with added red on shield rim; part of largely lost shield device in added white; red on helmet crest; exterior glazed; painted inscription on interior.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: For the subject, compare Taranto I.G.4442 (Brijder, H. A. G., Siana Cups I and Komast Cups. Amsterdam 1983, pl.15e, no. 52). Beazley attributes the sherd most probably to the potter Hischylos because of the retrograde inscription on the cup's interior. Hischylos produced cups with bilingual decoration and so Beazley believed this sherd comes from such a cup. While the cup is decorated in the black-figure technique on the interior, there is no extant evidence of red-figure decoration on the exterior of the vase.
Bibliographic references: Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 272, no. 61)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 434, no. B700)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 236, no. 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0619) (Phase 1)
Acquisition name: Donated by: British School at Athens
Acquisition notes: Presented by the committee of the British School at Athens.
